Tactic: initial-access

Selection: selection_keyword_2 (ID: selection0003)
  WholeLog|contains: Unclosed quotation mark

Selection: selection_keyword_3 (ID: selection0004)
  WholeLog|contains: near "*": syntax error

Selection: selection_keyword_4 (ID: selection0005)
  WholeLog|contains: SELECTs to the left and right of UNION do not have the same number of result columns

Title: HackTool Named File Stream Created
Rule ID: 19b041f6-e583-40dc-b842-d6fa8011493f
Category: create_stream_hash
Product: windows
Definition: Requirements: Sysmon config with Imphash logging activated
Technique: t1564.004
Software: s0139
Tactic: defense-evasion

Condition: selection

Selection: selection (ID: selection0459)
  Hash|contains: IMPHASH=BCCA3C247B619DCD13C8CDFF5F123932
  Hash|contains: IMPHASH=3A19059BD7688CB88E70005F18EFC439
  Hash|contains: IMPHASH=bf6223a49e45d99094406777eb6004ba
  Hash|contains: IMPHASH=0C106686A31BFE2BA931AE1CF6E9DBC6
  Hash|contains: IMPHASH=0D1447D4B3259B3C2A1D4CFB7ECE13C3

================================================================================

Title: Powerview Add-DomainObjectAcl DCSync AD Extend Right
Rule ID: 2c99737c-585d-4431-b61a-c911d86ff32f
Product: windows
Service: security
Definition: Requirements: The "Audit Directory Service Changes" logging policy must be configured in order to receive events. Audit events are generated only for objects with configured system access control lists (SACLs). Audit events are generated only for objects with configured system access control lists (SACLs) and only when accessed in a manner that matches their SACL settings. This policy covers the following events ids - 5136, 5137, 5138, 5139, 5141. Note that the default policy does not cover User objects. For that a custom AuditRule need to be setup (See https://github.com/OTRF/Set-AuditRule)
Technique: t1098
Tactic: persistence
EventID: 5136

Condition: selection and not 1 of filter_main_*

Selection: selection (ID: selection0787)
  AttributeLDAPDisplayName: ntSecurityDescriptor

================================================================================
Processing: DetectionRules/DetectionRules/sigma_all_rules/rules/windows/builtin/security/win_security_possible_dc_shadow.yml
================================================================================

Title: Possible DC Shadow Attack
Rule ID: 32e19d25-4aed-4860-a55a-be99cb0bf7ed
Product: windows
Service: security
Definition: The "Audit Directory Service Changes" logging policy must be configured in order to receive events. Audit events are generated only for objects with configured system access control lists (SACLs). Audit events are generated only for objects with configured system access control lists (SACLs) and only when accessed in a manner that matches their SACL settings. This policy covers the following events ids - 5136, 5137, 5138, 5139, 5141. Note that the default policy does not cover User objects. For that a custom AuditRule need to be setup (See https://github.com/OTRF/Set-AuditRule)
Technique: t1207
Tactic: credential-access

================================================================================

Title: Potential Kerberos Coercion by Spoofing SPNs via DNS Manipulation
Rule ID: b07e58cf-cacc-4135-8473-ccb2eba63dd2
Product: windows
Service: security
Definition: By default these events are not logged by default for MicrosoftDNS objects in Active Directory.
To enable detection, configure an AuditRule on the DNS object container with the "CreateChild" permission for the "Everyone" principal.
This can be accomplished using tools such as Set-AuditRule (see https://github.com/OTRF/Set-AuditRule).

Technique: t1557.003
Tactic: credential-access
Tactic: persistence
Tactic: privilege-escalation

  ObjectDN|contains|all: CN=MicrosoftDNS

Definition: Note that you have to configure logging for Named Pipe Events in Sysmon config (Event ID 17 and Event ID 18). The basic configuration is in popular sysmon configuration (https://github.com/SwiftOnSecurity/sysmon-config), but it is worth verifying. You can also use other repo, e.g. https://github.com/Neo23x0/sysmon-config, https://github.com/olafhartong/sysmon-modular. How to test detection? You can check powershell script from this site https://svch0st.medium.com/guide-to-named-pipes-and-hunting-for-cobalt-strike-pipes-dc46b2c5f575
Technique: t1569.002
Software: s0029
Tactic: execution

Condition: selection

Selection: selection (ID: selection0903)
  PipeName: \PSEXESVC
  Image|contains: :\Users\Public\
  Image|contains: :\Windows\Temp\
  Image|contains: \AppData\Local\Temp\
  Image|contains: \Desktop\
  Image|contains: \Downloads\

================================================================================

================================================================================

Title: CobaltStrike Named Pipe
Rule ID: d5601f8c-b26f-4ab0-9035-69e11a8d4ad2
Category: pipe_created
Product: windows
Definition: Note that you have to configure logging for Named Pipe Events in Sysmon config (Event ID 17 and Event ID 18). The basic configuration is in popular sysmon configuration (https://github.com/SwiftOnSecurity/sysmon-config), but it is worth verifying. You can also use other repo, e.g. https://github.com/Neo23x0/sysmon-config, https://github.com/olafhartong/sysmon-modular. How to test detection? You can always use Cobalt Strike, but also you can check powershell script from this site https://svch0st.medium.com/guide-to-named-pipes-and-hunting-for-cobalt-strike-pipes-dc46b2c5f575
Technique: t1055
Tactic: defense-evasion
Tactic: privilege-escalation

Condition: 1 of selection*

Selection: selection_MSSE (ID: selection0906)
  PipeName|contains|all: \MSSE-
  PipeName|contains|all: -server

Selection: selection_postex (ID: selection0907)
  PipeName|startswith: \postex_

Selection: selection_status (ID: selection0908)
  PipeName|startswith: \status_

Selection: selection_msagent (ID: selection0909)
  PipeName|startswith: \msagent_

Selection: selection_mojo (ID: selection0910)
  PipeName|startswith: \mojo_

Selection: selection_interprocess (ID: selection0911)
  PipeName|startswith: \interprocess_

Selection: selection_samr (ID: selection0912)
  PipeName|startswith: \samr_

Selection: selection_netlogon (ID: selection0913)
  PipeName|startswith: \netlogon_

Selection: selection_srvsvc (ID: selection0914)
  PipeName|startswith: \srvsvc_

Selection: selection_lsarpc (ID: selection0915)
  PipeName|startswith: \lsarpc_

  PipeName|startswith: \wkssvc_

Processing: DetectionRules/DetectionRules/sigma_all_rules/rules/windows/image_load/image_load_dll_rstrtmgr_suspicious_load.yml

Title: Potential DLL Sideloading Of DBGHELP.DLL
Rule ID: 6414b5cd-b19d-447e-bb5e-9f03940b5784
Category: image_load
Product: windows
Technique: t1574.001
Tactic: defense-evasion
Tactic: persistence
Tactic: privilege-escalation

Condition: selection and not 1 of filter_main_* and not 1 of filter_optional_*

Selection: selection (ID: selection1005)
  ImageLoaded|endswith: \dbghelp.dll

Filter: filter_main_generic (ID: filter0421)
  ImageLoaded|startswith: C:\Program Files (x86)\
  ImageLoaded|startswith: C:\Program Files\
  ImageLoaded|startswith: C:\Windows\SoftwareDistribution\
  ImageLoaded|startswith: C:\Windows\System32\
  ImageLoaded|startswith: C:\Windows\SystemTemp\
  ImageLoaded|startswith: C:\Windows\SysWOW64\
  ImageLoaded|startswith: C:\Windows\WinSxS\

Filter: filter_optional_anaconda (ID: filter0422)
  ImageLoaded|endswith: \Anaconda3\Lib\site-packages\vtrace\platforms\windll\amd64\dbghelp.dll
  ImageLoaded|endswith: \Anaconda3\Lib\site-packages\vtrace\platforms\windll\i386\dbghelp.dll

Filter: filter_optional_epicgames (ID: filter0423)
  ImageLoaded|endswith: \Epic Games\Launcher\Engine\Binaries\ThirdParty\DbgHelp\dbghelp.dll
  ImageLoaded|endswith: \Epic Games\MagicLegends\x86\dbghelp.dll

Product: windows

Tactic: persistence
Tactic: privilege-escalation

Rule ID: 407aecb1-e762-4acf-8c7b-d087bcff3bb6
Category: file_access
Product: windows
Definition: Requirements: Microsoft-Windows-Kernel-File ETW provider
Technique: t1003
Tactic: credential-access

Condition: selection and not 1 of filter_*

Selection: selection (ID: selection1028)
  FileName|contains: \AppData\Local\Microsoft\Credentials\
  FileName|contains: \AppData\Roaming\Microsoft\Credentials\
  FileName|contains: \AppData\Local\Microsoft\Vault\
  FileName|contains: \ProgramData\Microsoft\Vault\

Filter: filter_system_folders (ID: filter0443)
  Image|startswith: C:\Program Files\
  Image|startswith: C:\Program Files (x86)\
  Image|startswith: C:\Windows\system32\
  Image|startswith: C:\Windows\SysWOW64\

  CommandLine|contains:  ntevent

  CommandLine|contains: Get-WinEvent 
  CommandLine|contains: get-eventlog

  CommandLine|contains: Security
  CommandLine|contains: Windows PowerShell

  CommandLine|contains: -InstanceId 462?
  CommandLine|contains: .eventid -eq 462?
  CommandLine|contains: EventCode=?462?
  CommandLine|contains: EventIdentifier=?462?
  CommandLine|contains: System[EventID=462?]
  CommandLine|contains: -InstanceId 4778
  CommandLine|contains: .eventid -eq 4778
  CommandLine|contains: System[EventID=4778]
  CommandLine|contains: EventCode=?4778?
  CommandLine|contains: EventIdentifier=?4778?
  CommandLine|contains: -InstanceId 25
  CommandLine|contains: .eventid -eq 25

  CommandLine|contains: EventCode=?25?
  CommandLine|contains: EventIdentifier=?25?

Title: DLL Execution via Rasautou.exe
Rule ID: cd3d1298-eb3b-476c-ac67-12847de55813
Category: process_creation
Product: windows
Definition: Since options '-d' and '-p' were removed in Windows 10 this rule is relevant only for Windows before 10. And as Windows 7 doesn't log command line in 4688 by default, to detect this attack you need Sysmon 1 configured or KB3004375 installed for command-line auditing (https://support.microsoft.com/en-au/help/3004375/microsoft-security-advisory-update-to-improve-windows-command-line-aud)
Technique: t1218
Tactic: defense-evasion

Condition: all of selection*

-a always,exit -F arch=b64 -S syslog -F a0=6 -k disable_dmesg_logs

-a always,exit -F arch=b32 -S syslog -F a0=5 -k clear_dmesg_logs

Title: Turla Group Named Pipes
Rule ID: 739915e4-1e70-4778-8b8a-17db02f66db1
Category: pipe_created
Product: windows
Definition: Note that you have to configure logging for Named Pipe Events in Sysmon config (Event ID 17 and Event ID 18). The basic configuration is in popular sysmon configuration (https://github.com/SwiftOnSecurity/sysmon-config), but it is worth verifying. You can also use other repo, e.g. https://github.com/Neo23x0/sysmon-config, https://github.com/olafhartong/sysmon-modular. How to test detection? You can check powershell script from this site https://svch0st.medium.com/guide-to-named-pipes-and-hunting-for-cobalt-strike-pipes-dc46b2c5f575
Technique: t1106
Group: g0010
Tactic: execution

  PipeName: \atctl
  PipeName: \comnap
  PipeName: \iehelper
  PipeName: \sdlrpc

  cs-user-agent|contains: ${jndi:dns:/
  cs-user-agent|contains: /$%7bjndi:
  cs-user-agent|contains: %24%7bjndi:
  cs-user-agent|contains: $%7Bjndi:
  cs-user-agent|contains: %2524%257Bjndi
  cs-user-agent|contains: %2F%252524%25257Bjndi%3A
  cs-user-agent|contains: ${jndi:${lower:

  cs-user-agent|contains: ${jndi:nis
  cs-user-agent|contains: ${jndi:nds

  cs-user-agent|contains: ${jndi:iiop

  cs-user-agent|contains: ${${env:BARFOO:-j}
  cs-user-agent|contains: ${::-l}${::-d}${::-a}${::-p}
  cs-user-agent|contains: ${base64:JHtqbmRp
  cs-user-agent|contains: ${${env:ENV_NAME:-j}ndi${env:ENV_NAME:-:}$
  cs-user-agent|contains: ${${lower:j}ndi:
  cs-user-agent|contains: ${${upper:j}ndi:
  cs-user-agent|contains: ${${::-j}${::-n}${::-d}${::-i}:

  cs-uri-query|contains: ${jndi:ldap:/
  cs-uri-query|contains: ${jndi:rmi:/
